oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence from Arthur H. Harris to George Carroll Harris, November 11, 1860
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Arthur H. Harris to his brother George Carroll Harris in Nashville. He writes of the pervading excitement that has surrounded the 1860 presidential election in his area. Though he is glad the contest is over, he acknowledges the death of the Democratic Party, the long-standing absence of democracy and Republican form of government in the country, and the inability of the American people to self govern. His comments about the plans of Civil War are indeed prophetic.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harris, Arthur H., 1823-1873
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The stage was set for the conflict known as the American Civil War with the presidential election of 1860. With the Democratic Party broken into Northern and Southern elements, Republicans were able to put Abraham Lincoln into office without the support of any Southern state.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil War in the West; Civil War society; United States - History - 1783-1865; United States - History - 1849-1877; United States History - Civil War, 1861-1865
Civil Wars; War
